For I am that which has no name, I am that which is nameless. I am everywhere, knowing everything, I am immortal yet I shall one day die, forever going, one day stopping. My enemies will conquer me, but I shall holdfast for as long as I can, I shall be here. 
 
 I am that which is under your feet, I support you as you walk. I am that which feds, clothes you and gives you drink. It is me that stopped the rainy day, and it was me that made the rocks you stand on. It was me, and in my infancy I ruled the universe, but since then my enemy has grown more powerful, and I am fighting a losing battle.
 
 What am I? (Not god)
I don't suppose it would be nature?

 The Sun? good riddle!
The Sun would not be under one's feet or support you as you walk.

The Sun would not be under one's feet or support you as you walk.

 
 Sure it could, at night. And correct me if I am wrong, but without the sun we would cease to have gravity (orbit of the sun combined with the earths rotation provides gravity)...therefore we would have no force holding us to the ground (supporting us).

Sure it could, at night. And correct me if I am wrong, but without the sun we would cease to have gravity (orbit of the sun combined with the earths rotation provides gravity)...therefore we would have no force holding us to the ground (supporting us).

 
 Okay. The sun has no orbit that I am aware of. The gravitational attraction between the earth and the sun is what keeps the earth in orbit around the sun. The gravitation force between our bodies and the earth is what keeps us attracted to the earth. The latter of these has nothing to do with the sun.
 
 If the sun suddenly disappeared, the earth would travel in a near straight line tangent to its orbit around the sun at the time of said disappearance. It's path would be affected by nearby planets, but we would still be "stuck to the earth".

 Gravity is created by mass. Anything with mass has a certain amount of gravity. Even you have your own gravitational field if only a small one. So the earth is not dependent on the sun for its gravitational field.

Our universe is a four-dimensional hypersphere, which rotates about a five-dimensional axis which is orthogonal to a hyperplane containing the universe. The rotation creates centripetal acceleration, which is generally orthogonal to the universe's space in every point (and not perceived by the objects of the universe*). However, the centripetal acceleration causes curving of the space in vicinity of massive bodies. As a result, in the curved areas the acceleration is not orthogonal to the space, which appears to the universe's objects as gravity.
 
 Holy Gravity Batman
